The depth of the cavity away from the OIB transects is uncertain. The DInSAR signal supports the presence of water intrusions, but does not constrain the cavity thickness. A time series of Landsat images confirms that bumps in surface height present in the earlier part of the record, which are indicative of ice grounded on a bumpy bedrock, disappeared during the retreat, to lead to smooth variations in ice elevation, which are consistent with flotation (Supplementary Video 1).Conductivity temperature depth (CTD) data at the western Getz front show the presence of warm CDW near Berry Glacier as early as 1994, with an ocean temperature at 1,000 m depth around +0.2 °C (−0.1°C in 2000), increasing to +0.4 °C by 2007 (Supplementary Fig. 5b)14,25, i.e., the ocean heat flux must have increased during that time period. The bathymetry on the continental shelf includes deep and wide channels that should facilitate the access of CDW to the IGZ of Berry (Supplementary Fig. 6). We delineate a thalweg along western Getz, from the ice front to the east of 134° W, which may provide access of CDW to Berry IGZ (Supplementary Fig. 5a)21,26. More recent CTD data indicate a continued warming trend of CDW along the western Getz Ice Shelf since 2007. Temperatures increased from +0.8 °C to +1.2 °C at 750 m depth in front of Dean Island between 2007 and 2018 (Supplementary Fig. 6). Although these stations are not located directly in front of Berry, they provide strong circumstantial evidence for widespread ocean warming throughout the western Getz. The warming trend has been attributed to improved Ekman pumping over the Siple Trough shelf break, which contributed to the presence of warmer CDW in front of the western Getz Ice Shelf in 2018 compared to 2000 and 2007, and also facilitated CDW inflow onto the continental shelf to increase the heat flux available at glacier grounding zones25. Together, these observations support the interpretation that CDW intrusions, modulated by shelf-break dynamics and channeled through topographic depressions, have played a central role in the retreat of Berry Glacier.We compare the melt rates within 10 km downstream of the IGZ on the west Getz Ice Shelf for 2019–2022 (this study) with the inferred rates for 2003–200827 and 2010–201828 since we have data in this area for all three periods, but not inside the IGZ. Focusing on the area of coincident measurements, we find that the melt rate within 10 km of the Berry IGZ increased from 9.1 m/year in 2003-2008 to 14.9 m/year in 2019-2022. These values are higher than those for other glaciers, e.g., the DeVicq Glacier. The ocean temperature in front of DeVicq Glacier at 700 m depth increased from −1.2 °C in 2000 to +0.3° C in 2007, more than Berry, but unlike Berry Glacier, we find no obvious deep channel that would allow 700 m deep CDW to reach the IGZ of DeVicq (Supplementary Fig. 5). The difference in melt between the two glaciers increased from a factor of 1.3 × in 2003-2008 to a factor of 1.7 × in 2019–2022. The melt rates downstream of the IGZ of Berry are also the largest on West Getz Ice Shelf (Supplementary Fig. 7). The melt rates for Berry in 2019–2022 are 110% higher than the steady-state values calculated for the year 2007–2008, that is, assuming no thinning (Supplementary Fig. 7d), indicating that the ice shelf in this sector is 110% out of balance.From the modeled tidal height of  ± 1.2 m (Fig. 3d), we know that the average water in the IGZ cavity must be at least 0.6 m. If we assume that the cavity geometry tapers linearly from a maximum of 1.2 m at the entrance of the IGZ to zero at the inland limit, then given an IGZ area of 114 km2, a water flux of 0.7 × 108 m3 in 12 hours would translate into a mass flux of 1.6 × 106 kg3/s. Assuming an ocean temperature of +1.2°C, inferred from 2018 CTD observations near Dean Island, the ocean thermal forcing, referring to the salinity-dependent and depth-dependent freezing point of seawater, is +3.6°C at 1000 m depth. With a heat capacity for seawater of 3850 J/kg/K, this thermal forcing translates into a heat flux of 2.8 × 1010 W. If water intrusions flush the entire cavity during each tidal cycle and 30 ± 10% of the available heat is used to melt the ice with a latent heat of fusion of 3 × 105 J/kg, we calculate 0.7 ± 0.4 Gt/year of melt or an average melt of 6 ± 4 m/year, which is ten times lower than the remote sensing estimate for 2019–2022. The large difference between the back-of-the-envelope calculation and the remote sensing results is not due to an underestimation of ocean thermal forcing or the efficiency of ocean heat at melting ice; it reveals or confirms that the thickness of the water column coming in and out of the Berry IGZ cavity is much greater than 0.6 m, possibly by a factor of ten.While the relatively small ice volume of Berry Glacier limits its potential sea-level-rise contribution, our results carry important implications for ice sheet modeling in Antarctica and also reveal an enormous influence of this glacier on the mass loss of this part of West Antarctica. Most ice sheet models do not account for short-term variability in the GL position and assume zero melt at the GL2. Our observations show that these assumptions do not apply to Berry Glacier. The 18 km-long IGZ experiences a high melt rate, higher than anywhere else on the Getz Ice Shelf. The melt rate has increased in recent decades, as a result of the enhanced Ekman pumping of CDW. The increase in melt forced the GL to retreat, reducing the basal resistance to flow, allowing the glacier to accelerate, which is conducive to thinning and further retreat. However, the complex shape of the newly formed cavity, which includes ridges, over-deepening, and areas of partial grounding (Supplementary Fig. 8), must have limited the amount of ocean heat that can flood the cavity, and in turn moderate the rate of glacier retreat. A coupled ocean-ice sheet model, as in4, with a precise description of the cavity shape, would be needed to reproduce the observed glacier evolution.More importantly, previous modeling studies29,30,31 have shown that including seawater intrusions on a km scale in an ice sheet model increases the projections of glacier mass loss by up to a factor of two. The same conclusion would apply here in the case of Berry Glacier, that is, projections of its evolution will be higher when including seawater intrusions revealed in this study. In response to a warming of the ocean waters reaching the glacier, Berry Glacier has experienced an 18 km GL retreat, a 64% speed increase, and a mass loss of 131 ± 23 Gt, which is considerable for a single glacier. We recommend a more detailed characterization of the Berry cavity shape and continued measurements of ocean temperature and salinity to understand the physical processes that control heat delivery in the IGZ, melt rates, and retreat in more detail. Similar characterization should take place on other ice shelves in Antarctica.MethodsDouble-difference interferogramWe used ERS-1/2 (Supplementary Fig. 1a, b), ALOS-1/2 PALSAR (Supplementary Fig. 1c–h), S1a/b, CSK and RCM (Supplementary Fig. 1i–l) InSAR data to delineate the GL of Berry Glacier from 1996 to 2023. ERS-1/2 operated on a 1 day cycle in 1995-1996 during the tandem mission and on a 35-day cycle otherwise, at the C-band frequency (wavelength 5.6 cm), with a spatial resolution of 13 × 4 m, respectively, in the sloping range (cross-track) and azimuth (long-track). ALOS-1 PALSAR operates on the L band (wavelength 24 cm) with a 41.5° look angle off the nadir, 7.5 m × 4.1 m resolution (slant range × azimuth), a width of 70 km, and a repeat cycle of 46 days. ALOS-2 PALSAR operates at L-band (wavelength of 24 cm), has a 14-day repeat cycle, and in Stripmap Fine mode provides 10 m resolution over 70 km swaths. The S1 data are acquired at the C-band frequency (wavelength 5.6 cm), in a 6-day repeat cycle, in Interferometric Wide Swath (IW) mode, with a spatial resolution of 2.4 m in the slant range versus 13.9 m in azimuth32,33. CSK is a constellation of 4 × low-Earth orbit satellites operating in the X-band (wavelength of 3.1 cm) at a slant-range spacing of 3 m with a 16-day repeat cycle. The SAR images are formed by concatenating 3 × CSK STRIPMAP-HIMAGE overlapping frames, each 40 km × 40 km, at 3 m post in both azimuth and range directions34. RCM is a three satellite constellation that operates at C-band (wavelength of 5.5 cm) and provides a 4-day repeat cycle (12 days per satellite). The mission offers a wide variety of imaging modes, we focus on the high resolution 5 m (Stripmap) mode data at supported incidence angles between roughly 20–45°. We differ 3 (or 4) radar images to form a differential interferogram that reveals the differential tidal motion of floating ice during 3 (to 4) epochs. This approach enables us to separate the short-term vertical motion of the ice caused by tidal flexing from the constant horizontal motion of the ice35. The GL is located at the upstream end of a dense set of interferometric fringes (Fig. 2a, c, e). We manually map the GL in 93 × high-quality double-difference interferograms. When the fringe boundary is unclear or the fringes merge or split, we estimate the positive and negative errors based on the fringe pattern to show the farthest and closest distances that the GL may reach. We define GL positions for years 1996, 2008, 2009 and 2023, and IGZs for 1996 and 2019–2021. The limited data availability for 1996 may lead to an underestimation of the IGZ length in 1996, but we detect no residual signal upstream of the 1996 IGZ, and the annual series of ∂h/∂t along the flowline indicates that it is unlikely for the GL to have reached state 2 before 2006. One fringe is a differential vertical displacement, \(\Delta d=\frac{\lambda }{2\cos \theta }\), where λ is the wavelength of the SAR and θ is the angle between the incident line of the radar and the vertical direction. Multiplying Δd by the number of fringes, we calculate ΔSSH from the InSAR data.Tidal height calculation and correctionFloating ice flexes in response to variations in oceanic tides and atmospheric pressure. To quantify the tidal state, we use the CATS2008 model, which has a precision of 5 cm19 (Fig. 2b, d, f). We calculate the correction of the inverse barometer effect (IBE) at a rate of 1 cm/hPa36, using anomalies in mean sea level pressure from the fifth generation of atmospheric reanalysis of global climate (ERA5) by the ECMWF, with hourly outputs, at a horizontal resolution of 31 km20. We use the mean pressure for the period 2019–2021 as a reference pressure.Grounding zone length from hydrostatic equilibriumIf the ice is in hydrostatic equilibrium, the length of the IGZ is \(\Delta {L}_{HE}=\Delta h{[\beta+\frac{{\rho }_{i}}{{\rho }_{w}}(\alpha -\beta )]}^{-1}\), where Δh is the variation in the tidal height, the slopes of the surface α and the bed β are determined along the thickness gradients averaged over several ice thicknesses, and ρi = 917 kg/m3 and ρw = 1028 kg/m3 are the density of ice and seawater, respectively18. To calculate α and β, we use a WorldView DEM from September 6, 2019. The slopes are calculated along the direction of the migration of GL on a length scale of 3 × ice thickness.Ice velocity and surface height dataThe ice velocity is from MEaSUREs at a grid spacing of 450 m from 1996 to 202237,38. We used changes in surface elevation from ATL14 (land-ice DEM) timestamped to January 1, 2020 and ATL15 (land-ice height change) between 2019 and 2022, and MEaSUREs ITS_LIVE Antarctic Grounded Ice Sheet Elevation Change between 1996 and 2018. ICESat-2 produces a foundational DEM at a 100-m post and quarterly elevation differences at 1 km resolution that document surface elevation changes with reference to the foundational DEM39,40. MEaSUREs products offer monthly ice sheet elevation changes derived from 5 × radar altimetry missions (Geosat, ERS-1 and -2, Envisat and CryoSat-2) and 2 × laser altimetry missions (ICESat and ICESat-2) at a resolution of 2 km41.Ice mass balance calculationUsing ∂h/∂t along flowlines inferred from the elevation change products of ATL15 and MEaSUREs, we find that the IGZ reaches state 2 by 2006 and state 3 by 2012. We selected tracks from the OIB missions in 2016, 2012, and 2011 to serve as flux gates for 1996, 2006-2011, and 2012-2022, respectively, because the locations of the three OIB tracks overlap with the three states42. The OIB missions combine ATM altimetry and MCoRDS ice thickness. The ATM operates by emitting laser pulses toward the surface and measuring the two-way travel time, which is then converted into surface elevation data with an accuracy of a few centimeters. MCoRDS runs at low-frequency radar wavelengths (typically 150-600 MHz) to penetrate thick ice and detect internal layers and the ice-bed interface43,44,45,46,47. We calculated the ice thickness with the HE assumption at the designated flux gates for the period 1996-2022 by combining MCoRDS ice thickness with ∂h/∂t from MEaSUREs (1996-2018) and ICESat-2 (2019–2022). We apply the HE assumption only to regions where seawater intrusions are inferred at a specific time period. For the period 1996–2005, changes in ice thickness were equated directly with surface elevation changes, as the GL reached to state 2 around 2006. Between 2006 and 2011, the HE assumption was applied within the region from state 1 to state 2. From 2012 to 2022, HE was applied across the entire 2021 IGZ extent. By integrating these time-dependent thickness measurements with annual velocities in the direction perpendicular to the flux gates, we calculate annual ice discharge. We estimate the uncertainty in ice discharge by calculating its standard deviation from a central value in a region ± 1 km from the original flux gate.The annual SMB for the Berry Glacier basin is from the Regional Atmospheric Climate Model Version p2.3 (RACMOp2.3)48 with a resolution of 2 km with a 0.1 m/year error. The average SMB of the years 1979–2004, SMB1979−2004, is used as a reference surface mass balance that would keep the glacier in a state of mass equilibrium, to calculate anomalies in ice discharge, δD, and SMB, δSMB. The total mass balance, δM is δSMB - δD, which is independent of the reference period.Ice bottom and bed topographyWe used the ICESat-2 DEM and the WorldView DEM to deduce the basal elevation of ice in the IGZ from flotation. The basal elevation of the ice \({h}_{bottom}=h-\frac{{\rho }_{w}}{{\rho }_{w}-{\rho }_{i}}h\), where h is the elevation of the ice surface, and ρi = 917 kg/m3 and ρw = 1028 kg/m3 are the densities of ice and seawater, respectively. The WorldView DEM is generated from stereo imagery captured by Maxar’s WorldView satellite constellation with spatial resolutions of up to 0.5 m and vertical accuracies of 3 to 5 m49. Along profiles overlapping with OIB tracks, we utilize ice surface elevation from ATM minus MCoRDS thickness to calculate the elevation of the ice bottom. We also calculated the elevation of the bottom of the ice from the ATM. The elevation of the DEMs is corrected with the EIGEN-6C4 geoid of BMv3.7. Firn air content (FAC) is removed from all DEM using the values in BMv3.7, which uses a firn densification model50. Although we apply FAC from BMv3.7 to account for the density difference between snow and ice, we acknowledge that the FAC in IGZ is uncertain, as firn models may not capture the complex densification processes that occur in these transitional environments50.Along profiles A-B, C-D, and C-F, the bed layers are questionable because the bed echoes are weak and incompatible with our calculations of flotation, which is equivalent to setting up a minimum ice draft (Supplementary Fig. 4a–c). Level 2 MCoRDS data for the year 2011 are not robust because the values read from the level 2 data do not match with the bed line picked in the radar map, which is why we find many 100 meters difference between our calculated bed and BMv3.7. The blue stripey areas in Fig. 4g mark the regions where vertical motion from seawater intrusion is detected, but the bed depth is unknown. The white stripey areas show regions outside the IGZ where flotation cannot be applied and the BMv3.7 bed is not reliable. In Fig. 4h, the brown stripey areas are regions where the bed inferred from MCoRDS is not compatible with flotation and, therefore, incorrect. The absence of clear bed echoes at that location confirms that the elevation of the bed was underestimated from the radar echograms.Ice basal melt ratesWe apply an Eulerian approach to calculate the basal melt rates from mass conservation24 using ATL15 products39,40. The melt rate is \(\dot{b}=\dot{a}-\frac{\partial H}{\partial t}-(H(\nabla \cdot {\bf{u}})+{\bf{u}}\cdot (\nabla H))\), where \(\dot{a}\) is the surface mass balance, H is the thickness of the ice, u is the velocity, ∇ ⋅ u is the velocity divergence and ∇ H is the thickness gradient. Since ICESat-2 only provides elevation change relative to a single DEM, rather than absolute surface elevations at different time steps, as required for a full Lagrangian analysis, the Eulerian approach is the only option to calculate basal melt rates. This approach requires spatial filtering of the results to mitigate the effect of heterogeneities in ice thickness and bending stresses. We used a spatial filter of 4.5 km, which approximately corresponds to the size of the bending zone discussed by51. Since the ice in the IGZ is not floating during the entire cycle, the melt rates calculated along the IGZ may be overestimated. Using DEMs separated by one year, we exclude points within a “limit of viability” zone where the ice was grounded at the beginning of the integration period, equivalent to half the annual displacement (Fig. 6b). To evaluate the uncertainty in melt rate, we assume that the errors in the components of the mass balance equation are independent, unbiased, and follow a Gaussian probability distribution. We calculate an uncertainty of 21%, similar to Rignot et al. (2013) using an error in the velocity of 1% or 5 m/year, 3% in thickness or 30 m, 7% in SMB, and 20% in thinning rate.

items.title: Significant sensitivity of global vegetation productivity to terrestrial surface wind speed changes
items.body:

Article

Published: 21 October 2025

Significant sensitivity of global vegetation productivity to terrestrial surface wind speed changes
                    Haohao Wu 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0001-6978-91671, Congsheng Fu 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0001-7838-13231, Lingling Zhang2, Zelalem A. Mekonnen 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-2647-06713, Qing Zhu 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-2441-944X3, Kailiang Yu 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-0145-03564, Philippe Ciais 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0001-8560-49435, Jianyao Chen6, Dagang Wang 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-6424-63986, Huawu Wu1 & …Guishan Yang1,7 Show authors

Nature Communications

volume 16, Article number: 9315 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Climate changeClimate-change ecology

AbstractDecadal changes in terrestrial surface wind speed since the 1960s have been extensively documented, while the mechanism and the extent of their impacts on terrestrial ecosystem productivity remain unclear. Here, we systematically explore the impacts of wind speed changes on terrestrial gross primary production (GPP) using satellite-derived data, reanalysis datasets, flux tower observations, CMIP6 models, and exploratory simulation experiments. Our results show a negative sensitivity of terrestrial GPP to wind speed change, ranging from −156.67 to −65.82 g C m−2 yr−1 (m s−1)−1, across different data sources from 1983 to 2100. This is mainly attributed to the impacts of wind speed decline on stomatal conductance by reducing atmospheric dryness and soil drying. We find that during 1983 – 2010, wind speed decline is the most important factor, after rising atmospheric CO2 concentrations, in its contribution to the increasing trend in GPP (6.0% –7.8%). With further declines in wind speed, this contribution to GPP is projected to rank between second and third during 2031 – 2100. Among seven plant functional types, grasslands contribute most to the wind-induced changes in the GPP trend under current and future climates. These findings highlight the substantial effects of wind speed on centennial-scale global carbon dynamics.

IntroductionWind exerts significant influences on the structure and functioning of terrestrial ecosystems1, with some effects comparable in magnitude to those from changes in temperature and water availability2. The global land surface wind speed has declined by 8% from 1960s to 2000s, a phenomenon commonly known as “terrestrial stilling” in previous studies2,3. Notably, this decline is particularly pronounced in the Northern Hemisphere3. Although increasing wind speeds were observed after 20104,5,6, terrestrial surface wind speed is projected to continue declining in the 21st century, starting around 20307,8. Decline in terrestrial wind speed has been reported to stimulate vegetation growth9, extend the timing of foliar senescence2, and significantly affect plant transpiration and carbon uptake10. For instance, wind speed was shown to be a primary driver of net ecosystem carbon balance in semi-arid and dry ecosystems globally11,12. Over the past decades, global terrestrial ecosystems have been a strong carbon sink from enhanced rate of carbon fixation13,14 driven by factors such as increasing air temperature14, rising atmospheric CO2 concentrations15, nitrogen deposition16, and large-scale climate variations (e.g., El Niño–Southern Oscillation)17,18,19. Due to the complexity of the impacts of wind speed change on plant photosynthesis, to date, it remains highly uncertain whether and how the wind speed changes, besides the factors mentioned above, contributes to enhanced photosynthesis rate of global terrestrial ecosystems.Variations in wind speed are expected to influence photosynthesis through multiple biophysical mechanisms. Specifically, a decline in wind speed would increase boundary layer resistance3 and impede exchange of CO2 between plant and atmosphere, thus reducing the rate of photosynthesis. On the other hand, a decline in wind speed was also reported to reduce evaporation rate20 and mitigate water stress, thus promoting the rate of photosynthesis. Moreover, lower wind speed may increase air humidity and reduce vapor pressure deficit (VPD), which could enhance stomatal conductance and the rate of photosynthesis21,22. Existing findings on the wind speed sensitivity of terrestrial vegetation growth and corresponding carbon cycle were based on statistical analyses2,9,11. Unlike numerous laboratory and controlled field experiments conducted to examine the impacts of warming, drought, and free-air CO2 enrichment (i.e., FACE) on ecosystem carbon uptake23, field experiments focusing on wind speed remain largely absent, thus hindering us from understanding how wind speed variations affect photosynthesis without confounding with other climatic factors. In addition to the absence of experimental studies, to the best of our knowledge, there is also a lack of modeling studies that rigorously examine the relationship between wind speed and rate of photosynthesis. Exploring the effects of wind speed changes on terrestrial ecosystem productivity, as well as examining corresponding underlying mechanisms, is crucial for enhancing our understanding of how the projected decline in terrestrial wind speed may affect future photosynthesis rates.Here, we use three satellite-derived gross primary production (GPP) datasets, FLUXNET observations, three wind speed reanalysis datasets, and outputs from six Coupled Model Intercomparison Project Phase 6 (CMIP6) models, to investigate the role of wind speed change on the interannual variability and long-term trend of global GPP (Fig. S1). Multiple statistical methods and model simulation experiments based on the Community Land Model version 5 (CLM5) are integrated to quantify the influences of wind speed change on GPP (see “Method”). We are particularly interested in (i) determining the sensitivity of GPP to wind speed change (hereafter “∂GPP/∂Wind”), (ii) exploring the underlying mechanisms driving this sensitivity and illustrating corresponding influence pathways, and (iii) evaluating the contribution of changes in wind speed to the global trend in terrestrial GPP under past and future climates.ResultsDecadal variations of terrestrial wind speedFrom the reanalysis datasets and CMIP6 models, the global terrestrial surface wind speed exhibited a significant declining trend during 1983–2010, followed by a reversal from 2011 to 2030, and is projected to decline again from 2031 to 2100 (Fig. 1a; the identification of turning years is provided in “Methods”). Specifically, reanalysis datasets of the Climatic Research Unit (CRU)24, ECMWF Reanalysis v5 (ERA5)25, and the Modern-Era Retrospective Analysis for Research and Applications v2 (MERRA2)26 illustrated decreasing trends of −0.042, −0.017, and −0.031 m s−1 decade−1, respectively, in spatially averaged terrestrial wind speed from 1983 to 2010. Then, these datasets showed increasing wind speed trends of 0.039, 0.031, and 0.036 m s−1 decade−1, respectively, from 2011 to 2020 (Figs. 1a and S2a; regions affected by fire and human activities were excluded from all analyses in the study, see “Methods”). Consistent with reanalysis results, the spatially averaged terrestrial wind speed trend simulated by six CMIP6 models ranged from −0.070 to −0.009 m s−1 decade−1, with an average trend of −0.024 m s−1 decade−1, from 1983 to 2010. Six CMIP6 models projected average wind speed increases of 0.0041, 0.0058, 0.0092, and 0.0087 m s−1 decade−1 under the SSP1-2.6, SSP2-4.5, SSP3-7.0, and SSP5-8.5 emission scenarios, respectively, from 2011 to 2030. These models projected wind speed declines of −0.0078 to −0.0101 m s−1 decade−1 from ≈2031 to 2100 (Figs. 1a and S3). (The six CMIP6 models were selected from a total of 16 based on their data availability and their ability to reproduce the increasing wind speed observed during the 2010s.) Globally, both the reanalysis datasets and CMIP6 simulations have depicted a widespread decline in wind speed from 1983 to 2010, covering 66.64% and 71.62% of the global land areas, respectively (Fig. S4). The corresponding proportions of global land areas with increasing wind speed during 2011–2030 were 62.00%–68.68% (Fig. S4), while those with wind speed decline during 2031–2100 were 61.58%–72.21%.Fig. 1: Terrestrial wind speed anomaly and sensitivity of gross primary productivity (GPP) to wind speed change (∂GPP/∂Wind).Spatially-averaged terrestrial wind speed data (thick lines) and one SDs (shaded areas) in (a) consist of ensemble mean anomalies based on the CRU, ERA5, and MERRA2 reanalysis datasets (“Observation” during 1983–2020), CMIP6 simulations during 1983–2014 and CMIP6 simulations under four emission scenarios during 2015–2100. The spatial distributions of ∂GPP/∂Wind in (b) and (c) are the ensemble mean values based on nine analyses (three satellite datasets × three wind speed reanalysis datasets) and outputs from 6 CMIP6 models, respectively. The thick lines and shaded areas in (d) represent the latitudinal mean and one SD of the ∂GPP/∂Wind values in corresponding left panels, respectively. e The solid circles represent ∂GPP/∂Wind values at the selected 101 flux tower sites; the size of bubbles indicates the magnitude of the ∂GPP/∂Wind values. The violin plots in (f ) show the statistical distributions of the ∂GPP/∂Wind, with n = 101, 52733 and 16362 for “FLUXNET”, “Satellite”, and “Model”, respectively. Here, n represents 101 flux tower sites (each an independent ecosystem site), 52,733 valid grid cells from satellite-based analyses (independent spatial units), and 16,362 grid cells from CMIP6 model outputs (independent spatial units). In each violin, the shaded area represents the probability density, the darker band indicates the interquartile range (IQR), the white circle marks the median, the solid horizontal line represents mean, and the whiskers extending to 1.5 × IQR. Source data are provided as a Source Data file.Full size imageSensitivity of GPP to wind speed changes over past decadesA Principal Components Regression (PCR; see “Methods”) approach, which could mitigate collinearity introduced by other environmental variables such as air temperature, air pressure, precipitation, shortwave radiation, VPD, and atmospheric carbon dioxide concentration, was utilized to quantify the sensitivity of GPP to wind speed change (∂GPP/∂Wind) in the study. The calculated ∂GPP/∂Wind values computed through the PCR method using satellite-derived datasets (1983–2014), FLUXNET site observations (cover varying periods within 1983–2014) and CMIP6 historical simulations (1983–2014) all exhibited predominantly negative values across the globe (Figs. 1b–f, S5, and S6), suggesting that decreasing wind increased GPP. The median values of globally averaged ∂GPP/∂Wind using these three types of datasets were −65.82 (± 62.56), −121.65 (± 104.69) and −84.18 (± 79.55) g C m−2 yr−1 (m s−1)−1, respectively (Fig. 1f). Extending the analysis periods from 1983–2014 to 1983–2016 (or 1983–2018) did not significantly alter the ∂GPP/∂Wind results (Fig. S7). The ∂GPP/∂Wind values based on different data sources showed similar spatial distributions (Figs. 1, S5, and S6). For instance, the ∂GPP/∂Wind derived from satellite-derived GPP datasets and CMIP6 historical simulations both revealed lower values around ~50° N – 60° N and near the equator (Fig. 1d). In relation to plant functional types (PFTs), the identified negative values of ∂GPP/∂Wind for Deciduous Broadleaf Forest (DBF), Needleleaf Forest (NF), and Grass were more pronounced than those for Evergreen Broadleaf Forest (ENF) and Shrub from 1983 to 2014. The pronounced negative values of ∂GPP/∂Wind for DBF, NF, and Grass were consistent across different datasets (Fig. S8a–c).To further explore the sensitivity of GPP to wind speed change, we performed multiple simulation experiments using the CLM5 land surface model, driven by (i) baseline wind speed, wind speed uniformly (ii) increased by 1% and (iii) decreased by 1% and iv) detrended wind speed at each grid pixel for the period of 1983–2014 (The wind speed data used in these experiments was derived from the CRU JRA datasets; see “Methods”). Our simulation result shows that uniformly increasing wind speed by 1% led to a 0.40 g C m−2 yr−1 reduction of average terrestrial GPP (difference of GPP between experiments ii and i), while a 1% decrease in wind speed resulted in a 0.41 g C m−2 yr−1 increase of average GPP (difference of GPP between experiments iii and i) during 1983–2014 (Fig. 2c). The model simulated reduction in GPP with increasing wind speed (Fig. S9d) supported the negative ∂GPP/∂Wind derived from various data sources using the PCR approach (Fig. 1). Moreover, the overall terrestrial wind speed change by removing the long-term trend, i.e., wind speeds in experiment i) subtracted by those in experiment iv), was negative during 1983–2014 (Figs. 2a and S10b), verifying a widespread decline trend of wind speed during this period. This wind speed decline also induced increases of GPP (i.e., difference of GPP between experiments i and iv), especially from the late 1980s to 2005 (Fig. 2a) and over Northern Hemisphere (Fig. 2d and f). The spatially averaged value of the reduced GPP by removing trend in wind speed was 0.26 g C m−2 yr−1, close to the derived ∂GPP/∂Wind from experiments i and ii (not from the PCR approach) multiplied by the wind speed trend during 1983–2014 based on the default CLM5 simulation, i.e., 0.19 g C m−2 yr−1 (Fig. 2c). The GPP changes resulting from removing the wind speed trend in the simulation (Fig. 2d) also exhibited spatial patterns comparable to those obtained from ∂GPP/∂Wind × wind speed trend (Fig. 2f). Significant increases in GPP due to wind speed change occurred in 77.9% and 78.1% of terrestrial areas between 20° N and 60° N from the simulation and ∂GPP/∂Wind × wind speed trend, respectively (Figs. 2d–f and S11a). The consistency between these two calculation methods enables us to confidently use “∂GPP/∂Wind × wind speed trend” for computing wind-induced GPP trends under past and future climates (Fig. S1).Fig. 2: Gross primary productivity (GPP) variations resulting from wind speed changes from 1983 to 2014 based on CLM5 model experiments.a The temporal dynamics of spatially-averaged changes in wind (ΔWind) and GPP (ΔGPP): both ΔWind and ΔGPP are determined as the simulated values from the control run subtracted by those from the detrended wind speed run (control run–detrend wind speed run). Solid lines represent mean values, and shaded areas indicate ±1 standard deviation (SD) across grid cells. The violin plots in (b) and (c) show the statistical distributions of the spatially-averaged annual ΔWind and ΔGPP derived from wind speed trend extraction, with n = 32 for both panels. Here, n corresponds to 32 independent years (1983–2014), which serve as replicates in the temporal dimension. In each violin, the shaded area represents the probability density, the darker band indicates the interquartile range (IQR), the white circle marks the median, the solid horizontal line represents mean, and the whiskers extending to 1.5 × IQR. The rhomboid scatter in (c) indicates GPP changes contributed by the terrestrial wind speed trend, calculated as ∂GPP/∂Wind × wind trend. d, e show the spatial distributions of GPP changes that are induced by trend extraction of the wind speed (ΔGPP_1) and calculated as ∂GPP/∂Wind × wind trend (ΔGPP_2), respectively. The ∂GPP/∂Wind in (c) and (e) is derived from the results of CLM5 model experiments i and ii shown in Supplementary Fig. S9d, rather than from the PCR approach. The thick lines and shaded areas in (f ) represent the latitudinal mean and one SD of the values in corresponding left panels, respectively. Source data are provided as a Source Data file.Full size imageMechanisms of wind speed effect on GPPWind speed changes affect GPP through several mechanisms, including (i) altering leaf boundary layer resistance (rb) and the CO2 transport between leaf and the surrounding air, (ii) affecting stomatal conductance (gs) through its effect on plant hydraulics, (iii) changing leaf temperature (TV) and iv) modifying photosynthetic capacity (Fig. 3a). In our study, the negative ∂GPP/∂Wind values were caused by either increases of GPP with decreasing wind speed or decreases of GPP with increasing wind speed. The former case was more widespread, while the latter case was generally observed in the tropics where wind speeds have increased (Figs. S4–S6). The widespread spatial distribution of the former case was reasonable, considering that declining wind speed occurred approximately over 60%–70% of global land areas (Fig. S4) and that decreasing wind speed basically resulted in increases of GPP (Fig. S12). From our experimental simulations using CLM5, a 1% decrease in wind speed led to an increase (median effect: −0.50%; difference between simulation experiments iii and i divided by value from experiment i, see “Methods”) in boundary resistance, which reduced rate of CO2 transport and decreased GPP (mechanism i), and it also caused an obvious increase (median effect: −0.07%) in stomatal conductance (mechanism ii), which subsequently enhanced GPP (Fig. 3a, b). In contrast, it had limited effects (median effects below 0.01%) on leaf temperature (mechanism iii) and photosynthetic capacity (mechanism iv). Although the percentage change in boundary layer resistance due to the wind speed decline (median effect: 0.50%) was larger than that of stomatal conductance (median effect: 0.07%), the sensitivity of GPP to stomatal conductance variations was greater than that to boundary layer resistance (Fig. S13). This is because stomatal conductance directly regulated the internal leaf CO2 partial pressures, exerting a more immediate and significant effect on the rate of photosynthesis within the leaf compared to boundary layer resistance (Fig. 3a). Overall, the enhanced GPP due to decreasing wind speed through mechanism ii was greater than the reduced GPP through mechanism i (Fig. S13). Therefore, the predominant mechanism contributing to the overall negative ∂GPP/∂Wind was through adjusting stomatal conductance.Fig. 3: Mechanisms underlying the influences of wind speed change on gross primary productivity (GPP).a Schematic figure describes how decrease in wind speed affects photosynthesis via changing photosynthetic capacity, leaf temperature, boundary resistance, stomal conductance, and other intermediate variables. b One percent decrease in wind speed induces percentage changes of intermediate variables. Boxplots show the interquartile ranges (IQR; boxes), median (horizontal solid lines), and whiskers (1.5 × IQR), with n = 16362 for all variables. Here, n represents 16,362 independent grid cells from CLM5 simulations (independent spatial units). c Relative importance of VPD and soil water content (0–30 cm depth) changes in regulating the sensitivity of GPP to wind speed increase; the two percentages in (c) are the medians of the two statistical distributions. Data for (a–c) are obtained from CLM5 model experiments of control run and sensitivity run. Source data are provided as a Source Data file.Full size imageTo further examine the mechanisms of how wind speed changes affect stomatal conductance (gs; mechanism ii), we focused on two main factors along the plant hydraulic gradient, including VPD and soil water content27 (Fig. 3a). From our CLM5 simulation experiments, a 1% decrease in wind speed led to a 0.02% enhancement in relative humidity (RH) of canopy air and a 0.06% decrease in VPD (see “Supplementary Note 1” for VPD calculation); meanwhile, it resulted in a 0.07% reduction in soil evaporation and a subsequent 0.03% increase in soil water content (SWC) at depth of 0–30 cm (Fig. 3b). While the changes in VPD and SWC were relatively small, their impacts on GPP were significant, with specific global average values being 0.17 g C m−2 yr−1 and 0.06 g C m−2 yr−1, respectively. These significant impacts were due to the high sensitivities of GPP to changes in VPD and SWC, which were as large as 107.39 g C m−2 yr−1 hPa−1 and 15.49 g C m−2 yr−1%−1, respectively (Fig. S14). Decrease of wind speed led to more pronounced decreases in atmospheric aridity (measured by VPD) and soil drying (measured by soil water content) in high-latitude regions compared to other geographical areas (Fig. S15d–f). Mediation analysis28 can be used to determine whether a significant relationship between an independent variable and a dependent variable is partially or entirely explained by an intermediate variable, known as the mediator (see “Supplementary Note 2”). In this study, mediation analysis was further conducted to investigate the relative importance of atmospheric aridity and soil drying in modulating ∂GPP/∂Wind (see “Methods”; Fig. S16). Results indicated that both reduced atmospheric aridity and soil moisture deficit exerted positive mediation effects on ∂GPP/∂Wind, namely, accelerating the negative impact of wind on GPP, and atmospheric aridity exhibited greater influences compared to soil drought, as shown by its larger spatially averaged mediation effect of 17% (Fig. 3c) and widespread positive values across the globe (Fig. S15g).Contribution of wind speed decline to the increasing global GPP trendThe contribution of wind speed change to the GPP trend was calculated by multiplying the PCR-approach-derived ∂GPP/∂Wind by the trend in wind speed. We used wind speed reanalysis datasets, satellite-derived GPP datasets and historical and future simulation results from CMIP6. The CLM model experiments, which were designed to evaluate the influencing mechanisms, were not included in this analysis (see “Methods”). The increasing trend of GPP induced by wind speed decline during 1983–2010 based on satellite GPP datasets and the six CMIP6 model simulations was 0.25 and 0.18 g C m−2 yr−2, respectively. In contrast, the wind speed increase during 2011–2030 led to decreasing GPP trends of −0.057, −0.073, −0.033, and −0.18 g C m−2 yr−2 under the SSP1-2.6, SSP2-4.5, SSP3-7.0, and SSP5-8.5 emission scenarios, respectively. The projected wind speed decline during 2031–2100 is expected to result in increasing GPP trends of 0.21, 0.19, 0.15, and 0.35 g C m−2 yr−2 under the four emission scenarios, respectively (Fig. 4a). Notably, the increasing future GPP trends induced by the projected wind speed decline during 2031–2100 could be compared to, or even larger than, that during the historical wind speed decline period (1983–2010), although the CMIP6 models predict a slowdown in the decreasing trend of future wind speeds compared to historical conditions. This is attributed to the projected larger GPP sensitivity to wind speed changes in the future, with an ensemble mean ∂GPP/∂Wind of −139.74, −141.86, −151.93, and −156.67 g C m−2 yr−1 (m s−1)−1 during 2031–2100 under SSP1-2.6, SSP2-4.5, SSP3-7.0, and SSP5-8.5 emission scenarios, respectively (Fig. S17), compared to the historical period (−84.18 g C m−2 yr−1 (m s−1)−1 during 1983–2014). The CMIP6 simulation could reproduce the second largest contribution of wind speed to increasing GPP trend based on the satellite datasets, with the specific proportional contributions being 6.0%. Meanwhile, the corresponding contribution is projected to be 17.7% and 7.4% under the SSP1-2.6 and SSP2-4.5 scenarios, respectively, during the projected wind speed decline period of 2031–2100 (Figs. 4b and S23). Furthermore, grasslands contributed most (26.8%–73.3%) to the wind-speed-induced GPP trend changes among the seven PFTs during both historical and projected wind speed decline periods, as well as during the wind speed reversal period (Fig. 4c). The substantial contribution of grasslands can be attributed to the significant trend in wind speed and the evident negative values of ∂GPP/∂Wind within grassland ecosystems (Fig. S8). Additionally, the global prevalence of grasslands further enhances their impact. The pronounced negative values of ∂GPP/∂Wind within grassland ecosystems stemmed from the fact that an increase in wind speed led to more severe atmospheric and soil droughts compared to other PFTs. These droughts resulted in a more pronounced reduction in stomatal conductance, as indicated by our simulation experiments (Fig. S24).DiscussionIn the study, we investigated wind speed change, in addition to the widely studied rising atmospheric CO2 concentrations15, increasing air temperatures29, changing water availability30, and more frequent extreme weather events31, in affecting terrestrial photosynthesis. Our results showed evidence of negative sensitivity of GPP to wind speed change (∂GPP/∂Wind), and revealed that wind speed changes affected GPP primarily through its effect on stomatal conductance. Notably, the historical wind speed decline was the second most important factor after rising atmospheric CO2 concentrations, in its contribution to the increasing trend in GPP during 1983–2010 (6.0%–7.8%). To date, studies examining the relationship between wind speed and GPP are limited, but recent studies revealed significant enhancement of vegetation growth (e.g., extended date of autumn foliar senescence in high northern latitude2 and enhanced global LAI9) due to decline in wind speed during past decades, which is consistent with our findings on the negative ∂GPP/∂Wind responses. Our analysis showed that the significant correlations between wind speed changes based on different reanalysis datasets and phenological indicators (including the Start of Season (SOS) and End of Season (EOS)) occupied less than 20% of global land areas (Fig. S25). However, the phenological changes caused by wind speed variations are prominent in high northern latitudes2. The latitudinal statistics revealed dominant positive correlations between wind speed and SOS and dominant negative correlations between wind speed and EOS, which suggested that declining wind speed could potentially lead to an earlier SOS and a delay EOS and subsequently increase GPP to some extent. Existing studies2,9 also showed that wind speed was comparable to temperature, precipitation, and solar radiation in explaining the interannual variations of LAI (i.e., 31%–33%) during 1980s–2010s. Our study directly demonstrated that wind speed change played a comparable or even more important role than temperature in affecting the long-term GPP trend during the past decades and under the low emission future climate change scenarios. Here, we acknowledge that the use of approximately 30 years of data (1983–2010) may introduce uncertainties into the trend analyses. It is also worth noting that both the present study and previous studies have revealed the dominant influence of rising atmospheric CO2 concentrations on the increasing trend in GPP14,32, although the contribution of wind speed changes to the long-term GPP trend was not highlighted in previous studies.Currently, the terrestrial wind speed decline has been attributed to various reasons, including the increase in surface roughness due to urbanization and enhanced plant biomass33, reduced meridional temperature gradient resulting from polar amplification of global warming7 and decadal ocean-atmosphere oscillations such as the Tropical Northern Atlantic Index, the North Atlantic Oscillation, and the Pacific Decadal Oscillation4. Consequently, the causes behind the terrestrial wind speed decline remain poorly understood. In the study, we have conducted a Structural Equation Modeling (SEM) analysis (see “Supplementary Note 3”) to illustrate the influences of wind speed decline on GPP and the feedback of vegetation growth on wind speed. The SEM results revealed that while vegetation growth significantly increased aerodynamic roughness length globally (Fig. S26f–i), this increase only lead to a significant reduction in wind speed in 18.10% to 28.30% of the vegetated pixels globally (Fig. S26j–m). Moreover, the absolute value of the globally averaged standardized influence coefficient for wind speed on GPP (−0.18) was larger than that for surface roughness on wind speed (−0.04; Fig. S26a). For the pixels where surface roughness had a significant influence on wind speed (18.10%–28.30% of the vegetated area), the corresponding coefficients for wind speed on GPP and surface roughness on wind speed were −0.25 and −0.23, respectively. These findings indicate that, across the entire study area, the influence of wind speed on GPP was much stronger than the effect of surface roughness on wind speed. However, within the 18.10%–28.30% of the vegetated area, the strengths of these influences were comparable. As a result, decreased geostrophic wind speed and increased surface roughness jointly reduced surface wind speed in these regions, thereby enhancing GPP. The identified feedback loop of “GPP—vegetation growth—surface roughness—wind speed”, evident within 18.10%–28.30% of the vegetated area and particularly pronounced in the Northern Hemisphere, supported the findings of Vautard et al.32. For most of the study area (71.70%–81.90%), the nonsignificant influence of surface roughness on wind speed was consistent with the theories proposed by Karnauskas et al.7 and Zeng et al.4. The SEM results also aligned with the findings of Dunn et al.5, which suggested that decadal ocean-atmosphere oscillations drove trends in land surface wind, while vegetation growth, urbanization and instrumentation issues had less impact. Notably, the SEM analysis confirmed a negative influence of wind speed changes on GPP, regardless of whether surface roughness significantly influenced wind speed (Figs. S26b–e and S27). Even after excluding pixels where surface roughness significantly affected wind speed (18.10%–28.30% of the vegetated area), the contribution of wind speed changes to the global GPP increase during 1983–2010 decreases slightly from 7.8% to 6.9%, yet it remains the second largest contributor, following the rising atmospheric CO₂ concentrations.Although terrestrial surface wind speed trends can vary significantly with weather systems, seasons, and wind speed ranges19,34,35,36, the globally averaged annual values exhibited a pronounced decline from the 1960s to the 2000s. The causes of wind speed changes do not affect the reliability of the study’s findings, as results obtained from different data using both statistical and model simulation methods (i.e., PCR, SEM, and CLM5 simulations) were consistent. Notably, the model simulation experiments were implemented in an offline mode, where only wind speed differed between the various simulation experiments. This approach allowed us to isolate the pure effects of wind speed changes on ecosystem productivity. Furthermore, both CMIP5 and CMIP6 models projected declines in the model ensemble mean of wind speed in the future7,8. The simulations from CMIP5 and CMIP6 could, to some extent, capture the declining trend in future wind speed associated with increasing plant biomass and polar amplification of global warming (Fig. S3). Moreover, the increasing wind speeds in the tropics (e.g., Amazon), combined with latitudinal patterns, suggest that this is a global phenomenon likely due to reduced meridional pressure gradients. Thus, with increased temperature amplification, we might expect further decreases in wind speeds at high latitudes and, consequently, enhanced GPP.The increase in gross primary productivity (GPP) resulting from the decline in wind speed was particularly pronounced in regions dominated by grasslands (Fig. 4c). Interestingly, in another study9, grass was also reported to be the primary PFT that exhibited negative correlations between wind speed and annual LAI across the globe. More generally speaking, pronounced negative ∂GPP/∂Wind values were primarily observed in ecosystems where plant growth was highly dependent on atmospheric humidity, such as DBF, NF, and grass. Negative ∂GPP/∂Wind values were associated with significant positive correlations between Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) and atmospheric specific humidity (Fig. S28a). In contrast, ∂GPP/∂Wind was close to zero and even positive in regions where plant growth was not significantly enhanced (or even dampened) by higher atmospheric humidity (Figs. S5, S6, and S29b). For instance, plant growth in Amazon forests was restricted by excessive moisture and humidity during the wet season37,38, resulting in close-to-zero or even positive ∂GPP/∂Wind in this region (Figs. S5, S6, and S27b). Additional analysis was conducted to illustrate the influence of wind speed change on GPP via altering precipitation, and the results revealed that wind-induced precipitation changes contributed minimally (1.75%) to the total effect of wind speed on GPP at the global scale (Fig. S29).Regarding influence pathways, the decline in wind speed resulted in increased soil moisture primarily due to reduced evaporation. This phenomenon is supported by global observations showing decreases in pan evaporation rates39. Furthermore, reduced wind speed lowered atmospheric water demand, such as VPD, thereby mitigating atmospheric drought and water stress40. Previous statistical investigations illustrated that both the wind-induced increase in soil moisture and decrease in VPD contributed to an extended vegetation growth in autumn over high latitudes9. By analyzing vegetation physiological processes based on our model simulations, we have explicitly quantified the effects of wind speed change on photosynthesis via different pathways, e.g., altering photosynthetic capacity, leaf temperature, boundary layer resistance, stomal conductance. Our study provided quantitative evidence that wind speed decline enhanced stomatal conductance and thus GPP primarily through increasing soil moisture (i.e., by reducing soil evaporation) and reducing VPD (i.e., increasing the relative humidity of canopy air). We showed that wind speed declines during past decades effectively reduced water stress and mitigated drought risks22,23,30,31,41,42, minimized stomatal closure that ultimately led to a significant enhancement of terrestrial ecosystem photosynthesis. Our findings are consistent with two previous studies that also highlighted the prominent role of wind speed variability in influencing the carbon balance of semi-arid and dry ecosystems11,12. In contrast to our findings, a field experimental study suggests that increasing wind speed enhances plant carbon uptake under high solar radiation due to more efficient convective cooling10. However, compared to the large spatial and temporal scales of our study, the short duration (i.e., 30 min) and specific conditions (i.e., high radiation and leaf temperature) of these experiments10 may underestimate the drying effect and overestimate the cooling effect of increased wind speed. Overall, our study highlighted the substantial significance and the mechanism through which wind speed changes affect terrestrial ecosystem productivity, and thus centennial-scale global carbon dynamics. Consequently, the present study can help to reduce the uncertainties in Earth system models’ predictions of future climate change impacts on ecosystem carbon sequestration capacity.MethodsGPP and environmental variablesWe obtained GPP and environmental data at eddy covariance flux tower sites from the FLUXNET Tier 1 database43 (http://fluxnet.fluxdata.org). The environmental variables include wind speed, surface air temperature, air pressure, precipitation, incoming shortwave radiation, VPD, and atmospheric carbon dioxide concentration. Only sites with continuous observations of no less than 5 years and statistical significance less than 0.001 in principal component regression models (see the “Principal Components Regression” section below) were considered. Eventually, 101 out of 205 flux tower sites were selected for investigation (Table S1). The FLUXNET data have undergone a rigorous standardized data processing using well-established and published methods43, including (a) thorough data quality checks; (b) calculation of friction velocity thresholds to filter low turbulence periods, allowing an estimate of the uncertainty from this filtering; (c) gap-filling of meteorological and flux measurements. Notably, the friction velocity thresholds were determined through combing two methods: a change-point-detection method proposed by Barr et al.44 and a modified version of the moving-point-transition method originally described by Reichstein et al.45 and Papale et al.46. Additional, global phenological indicators, including the SOS and EOS, were obtained from a global annual land surface phenology dataset48. These indicators were calculated based on AVHRR data using the amplitude threshold method, with methodological details outlined in Wu et al.48.                 where \({\vec{{{{\boldsymbol{S}}}}}}_{{{{\rm{v}}}}}\) and \({\vec{{{{\boldsymbol{L}}}}}}_{{{{\rm{v}}}}}\) are the solar radiation and net longwave radiation absorbed by the leaf (W m−2), respectively. \({H}_{{{{\rm{v}}}}}\) and \(\lambda {E}_{{{{\rm{v}}}}}\) represent the sensible and latent heat fluxes from leaf (W m−2), respectively. \(\Delta {T}_{{{{\rm{v}}}}}={T}_{{{{\rm{v}}}}}^{n+1}-{T}_{{{{\rm{v}}}}}^{n}\), and the subscript “n” indicates the iteration time step. Further details regarding the partial derivatives in the above formulas and the heat balance within the canopy can be found in the technical note for CLM5. In CLM5, the stomatal conductance (gs) is calculated as61,$${g}_{{{{\rm{s}}}}}={m}_{{{{\rm{ft}}}}}\frac{A}{{c}_{{{{\rm{s}}}}}}\frac{{e}_{{{{\rm{s}}}}}}{{c}_{{{{\rm{i}}}}}}{P}_{{{{\rm{atm}}}}}+{b}_{{{{\rm{ft}}}}}{\beta }_{{{{\rm{sw}}}}}$$
                    (7)
                where mft and bft are specific parameters for each PFT (units: none), A is leaf photosynthesis (μmol CO2 m−2 s−1), and cs and es are CO2 partial pressure and vapor pressure at the leaf surface (Pa), respectively. βsw is the water stress index (units: none), ei is the saturation vapor pressure inside the leaf (Pa), and Patm is atmospheric pressure (Pa).In addition, a mediation analysis28 was performed to determine the relative importance of soil drought and atmospheric aridity (i.e., VPD increase) in regulating the sensitivity of GPP to wind speed change. From mediation analysis, positive and negative contributions of soil moisture and/or VPD variations to ∂GPP/∂Wind indicates a heightened and buffering effect of soil drought and/or atmospheric aridity on ∂GPP/∂Wind, respectively (see “Supplementary Note 2”).Data analyses were performed using MATLAB (version R2023b) and Intel Fortran (version 4.4.4). items.body:
Le tesi dell’inattivismo climatico – parte III: il nostro contributo è piccolo                
												
																																	                
					Ott 20, 2025Ott 20, 2025

Un altro classico del discorso inattivista sul clima consiste nel definire poco importanti le riduzioni delle emissioni italiane o europee, in quanto sarebbero solo una piccola quota delle emissioni globali. Generalmente si cita il contributo percentuale alle emissioni globali dell’Europa, altre volte quello dell’Italia, per dire che la loro riduzione darebbe scarsi benefici al clima del pianeta. Mettendo questi contributi in contrapposizione a quelli della Cina o di altri paesi. Altre volte si cita quale sarebbe la riduzione nelle temperature globali se solo l’Europa, o l’Italia, riducessero le emissioni, stupendosi del fatto che la riduzione sarebbe piccola.

È un argomento molto usato da Chicco Testa o sul Corriere della Sera. Ad esempio, nell’articolo di Amminiti e Pratesi già discusso nei precedenti post si è scritto: “le ricadute a livello mondiale sull’inquinamento ambientale sono abbastanza limitate, le emissioni europee pesano attorno al 7% e d’altra parte, se l’Italia eliminasse le fonti fossili la riduzione di anidride carbonica a livello globale si attesterebbe attorno allo 0,15%. Un risultato limitato, per non dire trascurabile”.

A parte che definire genericamente “inquinamento ambientale” le conseguenze delle emissioni di gas climalteranti è quantomeno sintomo di una scarsa conoscenza del tema, si tratta di un tipico esempio di benaltrismo.

Se si accettasse l’argomentazione che non dobbiamo curarci delle emissioni europee o italiane di gas serra perché ci sono altri emettitori più importanti, sarebbero allora tanto più insignificanti le azioni di tutte le Regioni, dei Comuni, delle aziende, delle persone in ogni parte del mondo: nessuno da solo ha cambiato il clima del pianeta; nessuno da solo lo può cambiare. Ma lo sforzo collettivo, le azioni dal basso sono una componente cruciale della lotta al cambiamento climatico. Che, ricordiamolo sempre,

può essere efficace solo se tutti fanno la loro parte, sia a livello di grandi numeri che di piccoli.

***

Dal punto di vista scientifico, la confutazione di questa tesi può basarsi su un concetto ben noto e non così difficile da capire: il riscaldamento globale non dipende dalle emissioni di un singolo anno, o di alcuni anni recenti, ma dalla cumulata delle emissioni. Ossia dipende prevalentemente dalle emissioni degli scorsi decenni e del secolo scorso. Questo perché la CO2, il principale dei gas serra, rimane a lungo in atmosfera (si veda questo precedente post): un quarto delle emissioni di un secolo fa sono ancora presenti nell’atmosfera.

Per cui l’indicatore importante per valutare il contributo al riscaldamento globale non è la fotografia delle emissioni di un singolo anno, ma le emissioni “storiche”, cumulate. Come si vede anche nella figura tratta dal sesto Rapporto IPCC, l’Unione Europea detiene ancora il secondo posto, dopo gli USA e prima della Cina, per quanto riguarda le emissioni cumulate di CO2 prodotte dalla combustione di combustili fossili e dall’industria.

Dunque, per quanto ora si stiano riducendo, l’Unione Europea deve assumersi la responsabilità di accelerare il più possibile verso la neutralità carbonica.

***

Ci sono anche altre ragioni per cui ha senso che l’Europa metta in atto la transizione a casa propria, hanno a che fare con il suo ruolo internazionale e con l’effetto imitazione che questo può scatenare

L’Unione Europea, pur rappresentando una quota limitata delle emissioni globali attuali, esercita un’influenza climatica  molto più che proporzionale  grazie al cosiddetto “effetto Bruxelles”: quando l’UE introduce standard ambientali stringenti (su auto, energia, finanza sostenibile, prodotti importati), le imprese globali sono spesso costrette ad adeguarsi per poter continuare a esportare nel più grande mercato unico del mondo. In questo modo, regole nate in Europa diventano standard globali de facto, generando innovazione, abbattendo i costi delle tecnologie pulite e spingendo altri paesi a decarbonizzarsi.

Questa influenza normativa si affianca al ruolo finanziario e geopolitico dell’UE, che è il principale erogatore mondiale di fondi per la finanza climatica internazionale e un attore centrale nei negoziati dell’ONU: senza la sua leadership, non esisterebbero accordi globali come l’Accordo di Parigi.

Inoltre, la transizione climatica è un classico problema di dilemma del prigioniero: se ogni Stato aspetta che siano gli altri ad agire, per massimizzare il proprio beneficio, nessuno agirà, e la crisi climatica peggiorerà per tutti. Qualcuno deve iniziare per costruire fiducia, creare alleanze e mostrare che la riduzione delle emissioni è possibile e vantaggiosa, socialmente e economicamente. L’Europa è  uno dei pochi attori che sta rispettando i propri impegni climatico, dando credibilità al processo internazionale e spingendo gli altri a seguire: non perché “virtuosa”, ma perché consapevole che nel clima l’inazione è contagiosa quanto l’azione, sia a livello individuale che tra interi Stati

***

Un altro aspetto da considerare è che le emissioni di un paese dipendono anche dalla dimensione della sua popolazione. La Cina è il primo emettitore mondiale, ma conta anche 1,4 miliardi di abitanti. Se si considerano le emissioni pro capite, si nota ad esempio che gli abitanti del Nord America emettono in media molto più di quelli di altri paesi.

***

Infine va ricordato che, se accettassimo questo argomento, allora sarebbe insignificante anche risparmiare energia, acqua o fare la raccolta differenziata.

Sorprende davvero che uno psicoterapeuta (Massimo Ammaniti) e il figlio di uno dei padri dell’ambientalismo italiano (Francesco Pratesi) possano ricorrere a questo classico pretesto, usato spesso dalle lobby fossili, per sminuire l’importanza delle azioni individuali contro la crisi climatica.

items.title: Emergenza idrica 2017, nessuno paga per aver messo a rischio l’acqua abruzzese
items.description:
Per il Tribunale di Teramo non ci sono responsabili per l'incidente che portò al divieto di consumo dell’acqua in gran parte della provincia
The post
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il Giaguaro In evidenza Adotta una specie Per il Tribunale di Teramo non ci sono responsabili per quanto accaduto il 9 maggio 2017, quando un grave incidente portò al divieto di consumo dell’acqua in gran parte della provincia. Un episodio che mise in serio pericolo l’acquifero del Gran Sasso, una delle risorse idriche più importanti dell’Abruzzo, da cui dipende l’approvvigionamento di oltre 700.000 persone. Una decisione che pone fine, dopo oltre otto anni di rinvii e ritardi, a un processo atteso da migliaia di cittadini e che riguardava la sicurezza di una delle risorse più preziose e fragili del nostro territorio. “Profonda amarezza” Pur in attesa di leggere le motivazioni della sentenza, il WWF non nasconde la profonda amarezza per un verdetto che lascia senza risposte una comunità intera e getta un’ombra sull’effettiva capacità del nostro sistema di garantire la tutela ambientale. È difficile accettare che, di fronte a un episodio che ha messo in serio pericolo un acquifero da cui dipende più della metà degli abruzzesi, nessuno debba rispondere di quanto accaduto. Il WWF, costituitosi parte civile ad altre Associazioni, sottolinea che la propria azione non è mai stata finalizzata alla condanna dei singoli imputati, ma alla piena ricostruzione dei fatti e all’individuazione delle responsabilità necessarie per garantire che simili emergenze non si ripetano più.Evidentemente, otto anni non sono bastati per raggiungere questo traguardo. Milioni di euro, ma ancora non c’è sicurezza Nonostante i milioni di euro spesi e la nomina di diversi commissari straordinari, la messa in sicurezza dell’acquifero non è ancora completata. Persistono criticità strutturali legate alla coesistenza tra le gallerie autostradali, i Laboratori del Gran Sasso e la falda sotterranea, con scarichi d’acqua non ancora pienamente trattati e barriere impermeabili incomplete. È inaccettabile che, dopo tanto tempo, non ci siano risposte né garanzie reali per la tutela dell’acqua e dell’ambiente. L’acquifero del Gran Sasso deve essere considerato una priorità assoluta: la sicurezza di questa risorsa riguarda l’intera regione e la salute di centinaia di migliaia di cittadini.

items.body:

Ecosistema Urbano: Trento e Mantova prime in classifica per performance sostenibili

20 Ottobre 2025

Legambiente

20 Ottobre 2025

Comunicati stampa

Città

La classifica di Ecosistema Urbano, il rapporto di Legambiente in collaborazione con Ambiente Italia e Il Sole 24 Ore, sulle performance ambientali di 106 capoluoghi di provincia.
Città in affanno sulla sostenibilità: ancora nessuna raggiunge il punteggio del 100%. Cala al 54,24% la media del punteggio su obiettivi performance raggiunti. Trento e Mantova, prima e seconda in classifica, uniche due città leader a superare il punteggio del 75%. Al terzo posto Bergamo che risale di 13 posizioni in graduatoria. Il Sud sempre in grande affanno, Cosenza unica città del Meridione nella top 20. Smog e rete idrica colabrodo le questioni croniche. In diminuzione piste ciclabili, isole pedonali e zone a traffico limitato. Cresce il consumo di suolo pari a +6,3 mq/ab dal 2018 al 2023 (+3,5%). Bene la raccolta differenziata: per la prima volta, tra i capoluoghi, si supera la media del 65%. In aumento il numero dei passeggeri sui servizi tpl.
Legambiente: “Serve una legge nazionale per una vera rigenerazione urbana potente deterrente anche per il consumo di nuovo suolo agricolo e una stabilizzazione definitiva dei bonus per le ristrutturazioni edilizie. Un intervento, quest’ultimo, da inserire nella legge di bilancio”.
Consulta la mappa interattiva su ecosistemi.legambiente.it e quella del Sole 24 Ore  
In Italia le città sono sempre più in affanno nel raggiungere performance ambientali sostenibili. La classifica dei 106 capoluoghi di provincia stilata da Ecosistema Urbano, il report annuale di Legambiente in collaborazione con Ambiente Italia e Il Sole 24 Ore, restituisce per il 2024 una fotografia in chiaroscuro. Ancora nessuna città raggiunge il punteggio del 100% e cala al 54,24% la media del punteggio raggiunta dai capoluoghi, registrando un -3,8% rispetto a due anni fa quando si attestava al 56,41%. Se si guarda ai singoli capoluoghi, nel 2024 sono Trento (79,78 %) e Mantova (78,74%) le uniche città a superare la soglia di 75 punti e a dominare la classifica di Ecosistema Urbano ottenendo rispettivamente il primo e secondo posto. Trento torna sul gradino più alto (nel 2023 era seconda) rappresentando il meglio della vivibilità in città. Mantova ottiene la medaglia d’argento risalendo la classifica di cinque posizioni (nel 2023 era 7 settimana), grazie ad alcuni risultati negli indici più significativi come il calo dei consumi idrici e delle perdite idriche e la raccolta differenziata che è all’84%. Dietro di loro si piazza Bergamo, al terzo posto con un punteggio del 71,82%, risalendo la classifica di ben 13 posizioni (nella passata edizione era16esima), grazie ad un impegno costante soprattutto nel settore della raccolta differenziata e della ciclabilità. Le altre città che rientrano della top ten sono Bolzano, quarta, seguita da Pordenone, Reggio Emilia, Parma, Rimini, Bologna, Forlì. Tutte aree urbane del nord Italia e con Bologna, al 9° posto, che si conferma la migliore tra le grandi città anche se perde una posizione rispetto alla passata edizione. Il Sud è sempre in grande affanno, ad eccezione di Cosenza, 16esima in classifica, unica città del Meridione nella top 20 anche se rispetto alla passata edizione perde 3 posizioni (era 13esima). In fondo alla classifica ci sono nove città del sud – Caltanissetta (97°), Caserta (98°), Catania (100°), Palermo (101°), Catanzaro (102°), Napoli (103°), Crotone (104°), Vibo Valentia (105°), Reggio Calabria (106°) – che non arrivano a toccare il 35% del punteggio. Crotone, Vibo Valentia, Reggio Calabria sono addirittura al di sotto dei 25 punti su 100.
Criticità urbane
Smog e rete idrica colabrodo restano le principali criticità da affrontare per i capoluoghi di provincia. Diminuiscono troppo lentamente le città con perdite d’acqua superiori o uguali al 50%: 20 quest’anno (erano 24 nel 2023 e 27 nel 2022). Nel 2024, inoltre, cala la media della superficie urbana dedicata alle infrastrutture per la ciclabilità – 10,39 metri equivalenti ogni 100 abitanti (11,02 m eq/100 ab nella passata edizione e 10,69 due anni fa) – così come diminuisce sia l’estensione media delle isole pedonali nei comuni capoluogo passando dai 50,7 mq ogni 100 abitanti della scorsa edizione agli attuali 48,6  mq sia quella delle zone a traffico limitato che nel 2024 si attesta a 368,3 m² ogni 100 abitanti rispetto ai 406,9 della scorsa edizione. Cresce, stando i dati Ispra, il consumo di suolo nel totale dei capoluoghi: dal 2018 al 2023 è pari a circa 4500 Ha, a fronte di un calo del numero degli abitanti (-346.000 abitanti). Ne deriva una crescita del suolo impermeabilizzato per ogni abitante delle città, sempre su base quinquennale, pari a +6,3 mq/ab dal 2018 al 2023 (+3,5% rispetto al 2018), con forti variazioni da città a città.
Buone notizie
Tra i segnali positivi che emergono dal nuovo report Ecosistema Urbano, c’è la raccolta differenziata che per la prima volta, tra i capoluoghi, supera la media del 65%. Inoltre, sono ben 15 i capoluoghi che sono oltre l’80% di RD. Cresce il numero dei passeggeri trasportati dal servizio di tpl nelle città capoluogo, anche se le performance generali sono ancora lontane dai livelli europei. Tra le città a prova di servizi tpl c’è Milano con 424 passeggeri nel 2024 rispetto ai 415 dello scorso anno, i 357 del 2022 e ai 303 del 2021. Anche Roma mostra lievi segnali incoraggianti salendo dai 259 viaggi procapite all’anno della passata edizione ai 277 di quest’anno. Venezia resta la migliore sebbene in calo, interrompendo una crescita costante, mentre Firenze prosegue a migliorare (sale dai 225 dello scorso anno ai 247 passeggeri/ ab/anno).
Priorità una legge nazionale per la rigenerazione urbana: Di fronte a questa fotografia, Legambiente lancia un appello al Governo Meloni chiedendo di approvare al più presto una legge nazionale per una vera rigenerazione urbana, potente deterrente anche per il consumo di nuovo suolo agricolo, e di avviare una stabilizzazione definitiva dei bonus per le ristrutturazioni edilizie senza farli scendere al di sotto del 50%. Intervento, quest’ultimo, da inserire nella legge di bilancio in discussione con le dovuta premialità per l’efficientamento energetico e per le classi sociali più deboli. La proroga di un anno sui bonus edilizi al 50% per la prima casa, che ha ottenuto il primo semaforo verde in questi giorni, è importante ma in questo modo è solo una soluzione tampone. Il Paese ha bisogno di città sostenibili, resilienti, efficienti, a zero emissioni, capaci di mettere davvero al centro la rigenerazione urbana anche per contrastare la crisi climatica in termini di adattamento e mitigazione. È su questo tema che si svolge una partita chiave anche per dare concretezza alla Direttiva case green per abbassare strutturalmente la bolletta energetica di famiglie e imprese. Temi e proposte presentate in sintesi oggi a Roma, al Palazzo Senatorio, nel corso della presentazione del report Ecosistema Urbano 2025 che quest’anno raccoglie diversi contributi a firma di esperti del settore e docenti proprio sulla rigenerazione urbana, citando anche esempi virtuosi in Italia e all’estero come Milano (riqualificazione ex area Ansaldo in un polo culturale e creativo); Bologna (avvio a quartieri misti che uniscano residenze, servizi e attività produttive leggere); Pisa (interventi riqualificazione urbana tra cui il Parco urbano di Cisanello), Lucca (messa a dimora di nuovi alberi in plessi scolastici).
“Le città italiane – commenta il presidente nazionale di Legambiente Stefano Ciafani – si stanno lentamente trasformando. Sono tanti e visibili i cantieri della transizione ecologica, ma sono ancora troppi i problemi irrisolti a partire dalla mitigazione e l’adattamento delle città agli impatti della crisi climatica così come il reperimento delle risorse finanziare dopo la conclusione del PNRR. Il Paese ha bisogno di interventi normativi e strumenti per facilitare una rigenerazione urbana adeguata alla sfida climatica a partire da una legge nazionale che fermi il consumo di suolo che non è causato dal fotovoltaico a terra, oggi vietato per legge, ma da altre infrastrutture. Serve anche rivedere il sistema dei bonus edilizi per rispettare gli obiettivi della direttiva case green. Senza dimenticare che occorre anche una consapevolezza tra gli amministratori locali che devono avere il coraggio di rompere gli schemi insieme a una nuova presa di coscienza nella cittadinanza che non si deve opporre alle opere della transizione ecologica. Le città italiane possono diventare un concreto campo d’azione di quel Clean Industrial Deal lanciato dalla presidente della Commissione Europea Ursula Von Der Leyen all’inizio del suo secondo mandato, ma dobbiamo crederci di più”.
 Il report Ecosistema Urbano nello stilare la sua classifica annuale prende in considerazione 19 indicatori suddivisi in 6 ambiti ambientali (aria, acque, rifiuti, mobilità, ambiente urbano ed energia). Riguardo gli indicatori, passati da 20 a 19, Legambiente precisa che quest’anno non è stato preso in considerazione l’indice ‘vittime della strada’ perché ISTAT ha cambiato le modalità di raccolta ed elaborazione di quei dati che ora sono focalizzati principalmente verso le città metropolitane e i grandi agglomerati urbani, rendendo di fatto indisponibili dati uniformi e validati per tutti i capoluoghi.
“La fotografia che emerge quest’anno da Ecosistema Urbano – commenta Mirko Laurenti, dell’ufficio scientifico di Legambiente e responsabile del report – evidenzia come le principali città del Paese fatichino a rispondere alle emergenze urbane e a programmare interventi tesi al raggiungimento di buoni livelli di sostenibilità e contrasto alla crisi climatica. Quello che manca è una strategia nazionale in grado di programmare scelte di indirizzo capaci di cambiare davvero le nostre città, rendendole più sostenibili, al passo con i tempi e vicine alle necessità dei cittadini. Per rilanciare il Paese occorre ripensare le città guardando alle emergenze di oggi, visibili dai dati, e a quelle di domani a cominciare dalla crisi climatica”.
Grandi città: tornando alla classifica di Ecosistema Urbano, interessante il posizionamento di alcune grandi città. Firenze dal 63°posto della passata edizione si piazza al 21° posto grazie ad alcuni miglioramenti, tra questi, crescono i passeggeri trasportati dal servizio di tpl (dai 225 viaggi procapite all’anno della passata edizione agli attuali 247) e migliora anche l’offerta del servizio; nella raccolta differenziata Firenze passa dal 55,7% dello scorso anno a oltre il 60%; e migliora negli indici dedicati agli inquinanti atmosferici. Torino, 85° nella passata edizione, conquista il 62° posto anche grazie alle basse perdite di rete, un buon numero di passeggeri trasportati dal tpl così come negli alberi messi a dimora su suolo pubblico. In negativo, oltre il biossido di azoto, le 75 auto circolanti ogni 100 abitanti. Roma perde solo una posizione in classifica, è al 66°posto.
I dati sulle città più verdi d’Italia sono consultabili online: l’indice di Ecosistema urbano 2025 è navigabile sulla piattaforma interattiva ideata dal team del Lab 24 del Sole 24 Ore
Inoltre, Il Rapporto e la relativa classifica sono stati pubblicati oggi sul Sole 24 Ore di lunedì.
